docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: Leveraging ​Artificial ​Intelligence for ​Skill ​Extraction &​ Research (LAiSER) is a tool that helps learners, educators and employers share trusted and mutually intelligible information about skills​.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Skills Extraction: Extract skills from job descriptions, course syllabi, resumes, and other text sources.
  • Skills Mapping: Map extracted skills to a common taxonomy (underlying implementation of taxonomy is subject to changes).
  • Levels Mapping: Map extracted skills to levels from 1 to 12.
  • Knowledge Required: Knowledge required to gain extracted skills.
  • Task Abilities: Task that can be performed using extracted skills.

docs.title: Contribute
docs.text: We welcome contributions from the community. Here are some guidelines to help you get started.

docs.title: How to Contribute
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository: Click the "Fork" button at the top right of the GitHub repository page.

  2. Clone your fork: 

      git clone https://github.com/LAiSER-Software/extract-module.git

  3. Create a branch: 
      git checkout -b feature-branch
  4. Make your changes: Implement your feature or bug fix.
  5. Commit your changes: 
      git commit -m "Description of your changes"
  6. Push to your fork: 

  git push origin feature-branch
7. Create a Pull Request: Go to the original repository and click "New Pull Request".

docs.title: Reporting Issues
docs.text: If you find a bug or have a feature request, please create an issue in the Issue Tracker.

docs.title: Style Guide
docs.text:
• Follow the existing code template style.
  • Write clear, concise commit messages.
  • Include comments where necessary.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• Python version >= Python 3.12.
  • A GPU with atelast 15GB video memory is essential for running this tool on large datasets.

NOTE

Google Colab is the preferred mode of execution

docs.title: i. Install LAiSER package using pip
docs.text:
Installing the package all the dependencies will be installed and downloaded: 

  pip install uv
  uv pip install laiser -q

docs.title: ii. Importing Skill Extractor from LAiSER package
docs.text:
NOTE

You need to also intall pandas and torch libraries to handle data and GPU-accelerated computations.

Install the required packages: 

  from laiser.skill_extractor import Skill_Extractor
  import pandas as pd
  import torch

NOTE: Python 3.9 or later, preferably 3.12, is expected to be installed on your system. If you don't have Python installed, you can download it from here.

docs.title: Usage and Output
docs.text: As of now LAiSER can be used a command line tool or from the Jupyter notebook(Google Colab). The steps to setup the tool are as follows:

docs.title: Google Colab Setup (preferred)
docs.text:
LAiSER's Jupyter notebook is, currently, the fastest way to get started with the tool. You can access the notebook here

  • Once the notebook is imported in google colaboratory, connect to a GPU-accelerated runtime(T4 GPU) and run the cells in the notebook.

docs.title: HuggingFace Setup
docs.text: • Follow this article to create an account in HuggingFace and activate access tokens to access the models.

docs.title: Create Colab Secret Keys
docs.text:
• Click the keys (can be found in the below image) button.
  • Fill HF_TOKEN in the Name field and your huggingface access token in the value field.

docs.title: LAiSER package Installation
docs.text:
• Install the laiser package using pip:

  pip install uv
  uv pip install laiser -q

docs.title: Importing Skill Extractor
docs.text:
• Import Skill Extractor from laiser.
  from laiser.skill_extractor import Skill_Extractor

NOTE

Import pandas and torch libraries to handle data and GPU-accelerated computations.

  • Install additional libraries:

   import pandas as pd
   import torch

docs.title: Initializing Extractor
docs.text:
• To initialize the skill extractor follow these steps:

 se = Skill_Extractor(AI_MODEL_ID="marcsun13/gemma-2-9b-it-GPTQ", HF_TOKEN="<YOUR_HUGGING_FACE_API_TOKEN>", use_gpu=True)

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
Output Column Descriptions:

  • Research ID - Unique ID of each job description.
  • Raw Skill - Skill Extracted by the model.
  • Level - Skill level mapped basis the description between 1 to 12.
  • Knowledge Required - Knowledge required to gain the extarcted skill.
  • Task Abilities - Tasks that ca be performed using the extracted skill.
  • Skill Tag - Unique ID of taxonomy skill that matches the Raw Skill.
  • Correlation Coefficient - Describes the closeness of Raw Skill and Skill Tag.
